head.title: Never Mind Those I.Q. Scores: It's Dedication That Counts; Breast-Feeding's Role

hedline.hl1: Never Mind Those I.Q. Scores: It's Dedication That Counts; Breast-Feeding's Role

block.p: Charles Murray and Richard Herrnstein produce evidence in their book "The Bell Curve" showing that the 15-point gap between white and black I.Q. scores remains even after controlling for all sorts of social factors. But there is one factor they do not discuss.

Charles Murray and Richard Herrnstein produce evidence in their book "The Bell Curve" showing that the 15-point gap between white and black I.Q. scores remains even after controlling for all sorts of social factors. But there is one factor they do not discuss.

Alan Lucas, a British pediatric nutritionist, provided conclusive evidence in the January 1993 issue of the British medical journal The Lancet that babies breast-fed in the first month of life score 8.3 points above the average I.Q. at age 8; other studies have shown further gains for every additional month the infant was breast-fed (three points a month between 6 and 12 months).

In the African-American culture in the United States, babies are seldom breast-fed. According to officials of La Leche League International, the incidence is about 8 percent, while for whites the figure is 54 percent. I contend that the persistent 15-point gap in I.Q. is due to this large disparity in infant breastfeeding practices, and that this factor must be controlled for when assessing the sources of such a gap. VALERIE M. HUDSON Assoc. Prof. of Political Science Brigham Young University Provo, Utah, Oct. 28, 1994
